awd_titl_txt: Investigations in Combinatorics and Number Theory via Ergodic Theoretic Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
Historically, the theory of dynamical systems was rooted in the study of the movement of macroscopic objects (such as moons, planets, etc.) and microscopic particles (such as molecules and atoms). Today, it is a vast area that pursues the study of orbits and transformations in general systems evolving with time. It is a rich and active research area that not only plays an important role in contemporary mathematics, but also greatly contributes to other sciences and finds many applications. This project seeks to improve upon the analytic tools and techniques available in dynamical systems, with anticipated impact in a wide range of fields.

The primary objectives of this project are concentrated at the interface of three different areas in pure mathematics: the theory of dynamical systems, combinatorics, and number theory. The employment of analytic tools stemming from measurable, topological, and symbolic dynamics often offers novel ways to analyze number-theoretic and combinatorial situations. This approach has proven to be powerful in solving seemingly intractable problems. In the same vein, this project aims to address, and potentially settle, conjectures and open questions in arithmetic combinatorics and number theory with the help of dynamical methods. The main challenges of the project range from recasting problems in discrete mathematics in a dynamical language to developing the pertinent dynamical tools for solving these reformulations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The patterns that must show up in any sufficiently large set of integers have been studied for over a hundred years, and many different patterns are known to occur in any set that has sufficient density, meaning it contains a positive percentage of the integers. Examples of such patterns include arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions, patterns using polynomial differences, and patterns using prime numbers.  The common feature of these patterns is that they are all finite.   In joint work with collaborators, the PI showed that existence of certain infinite patters in any set of integers having positive density.  The methods of proof use tools from ergodic theory, leading to deepr connections between dynamical questions and combiantorial ones.  

The PI was involved in the training and mentoring of numerous graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and undergraduates, with the goal of increasing the number of researchers who can work on problems at the inferface of ergodic theory and combinatorics.  This involves weekly meetings for discussing new advances, along with running and participating in a  more traditional weekly research seminar.   In addition, the PI has given numerous talks on the recent work, including several minicourses, and has published the results in peer reviewed journals and on her website. In summer 2024, the PI is one of the organizers of a week long summer school followed by a week long conference on topics at the inferface of ergodic theory and combiantorics, and approximately 100 people are expected to attend.
